title: What is the most misunderstood statement that someone has said in history? - Quora

response.answer_text: Famous Quote: “Good fences make good neighbors.” Privacy is the theme this Robert Frost quote and while the phrase “good fences make good neighbors” is not quite so famous as some others (though you’ve certainly heard it), Mending Wall Is one that needs to be included for one simple reason: it’s misunderstood by federal law. “Separation of powers, a distinctively American political doctrine, profits from the advice authored by a distinctively American poet: Good fences make good neighbors.” That’s United States Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, literally creating hard law from thin air, and not understanding the thing he’s talking about. Mending Wall does include the line “good fences make good neighbors,” but it also paints the character speaking that line as a bit of a twit. “Something there is that doesn’t love a wall… (nature) sends the frozen groundswell under it.” The poem tells a story of two neighbors with a wall between them, but every winter the wall falls apart, so the neighbors have to meet and mend the wall, spending more time together than they otherwise would have and growing increasingly frustrated with the each other. Remember that the Supreme Court has nine justices, and at least one (Stephen Breyer) actually pointed out the error in his concurring opinion, but Scalia decided to leave the mistake in anyway. Breyer dissent:”As the majority invokes the advice of an American poet, one might consider as well that poet's caution, for he not only notes that “Something there is that doesn't love a wall,” but also writes, “Before I built a wall I'd ask to know/ What I was walling in or walling out.” R. Frost, Mending Wall, The New Oxford Book of American Verse 395–396 (R. Ellmann ed. 1976).” Ed PLAUT, et ux., et al., Petitioners, v. SPENDTHRIFT FARM, INC., et al.

Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain. Most people believe that saying “Oh my God!” is a sin against one of the 10 commandments. But the more you look at it from this perspective, the more petty and silly this commandment sounds. But the inherent commandment isn’t that superficial, at least not as superficial as thought of to be. People mistake this commandment for swearing, a lot. What the commandment actually means: Not to make vows and commitments by God’s name (as the witness) so lightly.To claim that your own will and actions is God’s will.Which means things like Wedding vows, swearing in as President, preaching, etc, are all potential acts of breaking the commandment. “Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain” essentially means; “Don’t say God said it when he didn’t” and/or “Don’t make false promises and use God as a witness.” It’s a commandment a lot of Christians hypocritically break a lot more than they think.
